questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a fall that occurred while he was taking a shower earlier that morning. His wife heard him fall and entered the bathroom to find his arms and legs twitching. The episode lasted approximately 30 seconds. He was unsure of what had happened and was unable to answer simple questions on awakening. He has regained orientation since that time. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metoprolol and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. He has 5/5 strength in all extremities. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is normal and symmetrical. A noncontrast head CT is performed and shows a slightly hyperdense mass. Follow-up MRI shows a homogeneous, well-circumscribed 4-cm mass with compression of the adjacent white matter, and a hyperintense border around the mass on T2-weighted imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and can manifest with seizures. On CT scan, however, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intraaxial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. On T2-weighted MRI, glioblastoma multiforme typically appears as an expansive hyperintense signal, which represents vasogenic edema involving both the cortex and underlying white matter. The presence of a well-circumscribed, extraaxial mass makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastoma

The right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.

Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification

B) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and commonly manifest with seizures. However, oligodendrogliomas usually appear on CT as hypodense, intraaxial tumors with focal hyperdense regions within the tumor, which are caused by calcification and/or hemorrhage.
Image Description:

MRI head (FLAIR sequence; axial plane)

A hyperintense area (green overlay) in the right medial temporooccipital region was hypointense on a contrast-enhanced T1-weighted sequence (not shown). The lesion proved to be an oligodendroglioma. The differential diagnosis on MRI also included ischemic and inflammatory processes.

C: cerebellum; M: mesencephalon (midbrain)

C) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuroma, the most common type of schwannoma, is especially common in patients 40–60 years of age. However, seizure would be an uncommon symptom of an infratentorial tumor such as an acoustic neuroma. Instead, patients typically present with sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and facial nerve palsy. Additionally, acoustic neuromas, while generally best visualized on gadolinium-enhanced MRI, appear on noncontrast T2-weighted imaging as heterogeneously hyperintense extraaxial lesions that are localized to the cerebellopontine angle, the internal auditory meatus, and/or the internal auditory canal.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cranial hemangioblastomas are almost always infratentorial tumors. As a result, they manifest with features of elevated intracranial pressure, cerebellar dysfunction, and/or palsies of cranial nerves that arise from the pons and medulla oblongata. On CT scan, they appear as sharply demarcated, hypodense, intraaxial cystic lesions. The presence of seizures and a hyperdense, extraaxial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of hemangioblastoma unlikely.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas are intraaxial tumors that most commonly occur near the cerebellar midline. Since medulloblastomas are infratentorial tumors, seizures are uncommon. Instead, features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting, papilledema) and cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., ataxia, nystagmus) are typically present. On CT, medulloblastomas appear as hyperdense tumors in the cerebellum, with possible diffuse infiltration of the fourth ventricle and brainstem. This patient's presentation with seizures and the extraaxial location of the lesion make a medulloblastoma highly unlikely.
Image Description:

Head MRI (T2 weighted image)

Medulloblastoma within the posterior cranial fossa (green border in overlay). The lesion contains cystic areas, particularly on the left side (green overlay).

F) CORRECT:

Meningiomas are tumors derived from the meninges and occur supratentorially (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove) in about half of all cases. Meningiomas may be asymptomatic or cause general symptoms of brain tumors such as seizures and/or specific patterns of symptoms depending on their location. On CT, meningiomas appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extraaxial mass that is usually hyperdense. On plain MRIs, meningiomas may appear isointense to gray matter on T1 and hyperintense to gray matter on T2.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).
questions.hint: Brain tumors that manifest with seizures are most often supratentorial. The compression of adjacent white matter and/or a rim of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) around the tumor (hyperintense appearance of CSF on T2-weighted imaging) indicate that the tumor is most likely extraaxial (external to the brain parenchyma).

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of paresthesias and weakness in her left leg for one year. Her symptoms have become progressively worse during this period and have led to some difficulty walking for the past month. She has had frequent headaches for the past 4 months. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. Current medications include amlodipine and levothyroxine. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows decreased muscle strength in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes of the lower extremity are 4+ on the left and 2+ on the right side. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, creatinine, and calcium are within the reference ranges. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Surgical resection is the first-line treatment for most meningiomas. This patient's large meningioma is located on the convex surface of the cerebrum and is easily accessible via parietal craniotomy. Complete surgical resection of the meningioma ensures the lowest chance of recurrence. Focused radiotherapy (stereotactic radiotherapy) is indicated in inoperable tumors (e.g., meningiomas near the optic sheath or critical structures at the base of the skull) or if the tumor is incompletely resected.

Symptoms are determined by the location of the tumor. However, most meningiomas are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.

B) INCORRECT:

Whole brain radiotherapy is indicated for patients with multiple brain metastases. Brain metastasis can manifest with a headache and neurological deficits (such as motor and sensory deficits), but they typically occur intraaxially in the grey-white matter junction (and are not attached to the dura, as seen here), making it an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis as well as for histological grading of meningiomas. Histological grading is important for guiding further management. Stereotactic brain biopsy is indicated as the next best step if the tumor is inoperable (e.g., tumors at the base of the skull) and/or if stereotactic radiosurgery is being considered as the first-line treatment. In this patient, however, a biopsy can be performed in the pathological specimen that is obtained via first-line management, and a stereotactic brain biopsy is not required.

D) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiosurgery is the first-line treatment for small meningiomas (usually < 3 cm) in patients who are poor candidates for surgical resection (e.g., meningiomas near the optic sheath or critical structures at the base of the skull). Stereotactic surgery is not the treatment of choice for large, easily accessible meningiomas, as is the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Active surveillance via serial imaging is indicated for small, asymptomatic meningiomas that are discovered incidentally on imaging. It is not appropriate in a patient with neurological deficits.

F) INCORRECT:

Intrathecal chemotherapy with methotrexate is typically used for the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia with CNS invasion or primary CNS lymphomas. These tumors may manifest with focal neurological deficits, headaches, and a space-occupying lesion. However, acute lymphoblastic leukemia typically occurs during childhood and would manifest with an abnormal complete blood count. This patient also does not have risk factors for a primary CNS lymphoma (e.g., immunosuppression). Moreover, both of these tumors are usually intra-axial lesions. Intrathecal chemotherapy with methotrexate is not useful for the treatment of meningiomas because they respond poorly to chemotherapy.

G) INCORRECT:

Temozolomide is typically used in the treatment of glioblastoma multiforme. However, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum, unlike the well-demarcated, extraaxial lesion seen here.
questions.hint: Focal weakness and paresthesia of the left lower extremity with hyperreflexia on the same side are consistent with an upper motor neuron lesion. The MRI confirms the location of the tumor and shows a round, well-demarcated, extraaxial tumor with a dural tail in the parasagittal cortical region, which is highly suggestive of a meningioma.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of increasing weakness of her extremities and neck pain that is worse on coughing or sneezing. She first noticed weakness of her right upper extremity 3 years ago, which progressed to her right lower extremity 2 years ago, her left lower extremity 1 year ago, and her left upper extremity 6 months ago. She has had difficulty swallowing and speaking for the past 5 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an ataxic gait. Speech is dysarthritic. Muscular examination shows spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. There is bilateral atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar response shows an extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to touch is decreased over all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although the falx cerebri, the supratentorial convex surface, and the sphenoidal wings are the most common locations of meningiomas, in rare cases they also occur at the foramen magnum. Since meningiomas are slow-growing tumors, patients usually present after several months to years of slowly progressive symptoms. Early features include neck pain, which is typically worse with neck flexion and maneuvers that increase ICP (e.g., coughing, sneezing). Later, patients with meningiomas at the foramen magnum present with long tract signs and a characteristic pattern of symptom distribution: sensory and motor deficits typically start in one extremity and spread to the others. Late presentation is characterized by spastic quadriparesis (hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign), gait disturbances, and lower cranial nerve palsies (CN IX–XII), which most likely accounts for this patient's dysarthria and atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
Image Description:

MRI of the neck and base of the skull (left: T1-weighted, with contrast, sagittal plane; right: T2-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is a well-defined mass in the anterior aspect of the foramen magnum, which enhances on the T1-weighted post-contrast image (red overlay) and appears hyperintense to gray matter on the T2-weighted image (green overlay). The mass is continuous with the adjacent thickened and enhancing dura (arrowhead). This is known as the “dural tail sign.”

The dural tail sign suggests lesion originates from the dura mater. The sign is most commonly seen in meningiomas but may also be seen in other malignancies originating in the dura mater, such as lymphoma and metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytomas are grade I (benign) astrocytomas that are often localized in the cerebellum and most frequently occur in children and young adults. Signs of cerebellar masses include symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, and vomiting), ataxia, and possibly failure to thrive. While an ataxic gait could be caused by a cerebellar tumor, this patient's muscle weakness, sensory symptoms, and dysarthria suggest another diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a child

A large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).

Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

In syringomyelia, the compression from the fluid-filled cavity within the central spinal cord results in neck pain and a cape-like distribution (neck, shoulders, arms) of dissociated sensory loss, which develops over years. The sensory symptoms in syringomyelia are often exacerbated by maneuvers that increase the intramedullary pressure, such as coughing or sneezing. Muscle atrophy is another common feature of syringomyelia and most commonly affects the small muscles of the hand. Other signs of lower motor neuron lesion, such as fasciculations and areflexia (rather than this patient's hyperreflexia), may also be present. While spastic paraparesis of the limbs is a possible feature of syringomyelia due to involvement of the pyramidal tract and first motor neuron, quadriparesis is uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with signs of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spastic paresis, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron involvement (e.g., atrophy), both of which are present in this patient. ALS may also initially manifest with bulbar symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and/or asymmetrical limb weakness, which often begins unilaterally in an upper extremity and progresses with the disease. However, this patient's sensory symptoms are not consistent with ALS, which is a motor neuron disease.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

In multiple sclerosis (MS), demyelination of CNS neurons may result in upper motor neuron weakness characterized by spasticity, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign. Dysarthria is also present in almost half of all MS cases at some point during the course of the disease. However, the most common course of MS is relapsing-remitting, which progresses with alternating phases of exacerbations and remission rather than simply progressive. Also, atrophy of the muscles innervated by cranial nerve XI is not a typical feature of MS.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

At the level of the fourth cervical vertebral body, there is an area of poorly defined hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay). The first cervical vertebra is not well visualized in this image due to its shape, whereas the second cervical vertebra is well recognized due to the superior projected bony element known as the dens or odontoid process.

This is an example of a demyelinating plaque in a patient with multiple sclerosis. Spinal cord demyelinating plaques from multiple sclerosis are most often found in the cervical segment of the cord. They are usually shorter than two vertebral bodies in length.

F) INCORRECT:

A glioblastoma multiforme is most commonly located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and therefore most frequently manifests with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, seizures). Symptoms develop over a short period of time (several weeks) due to rapid growth of the tumor. While the condition can manifest with motor weakness, the pattern of symptom progression over 3 years seen in this patient is not consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.
Image Description:

T1-weighted contrast-enhanced MRI, frontal view: bihemisphere garland-like contrast enhancement. There is peripheral contrast agent enhancement (blue overlay) with central necrosis (green overlay). The third ventricle (arrowhead) is centrally located. The tumor is displacing the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle (red overlay). Diagnosis: bilateral glioblastoma (butterfly glioma).
questions.hint: The pattern of this patient's symptom progression suggests CNS compression in a particular location.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-year history of upper and lower extremity weakness and neck pain that is worse with sneezing. She has had difficulty swallowing and speaking for the past 8 months. Musculoskeletal examination shows spasticity and decreased muscle strength in all extremities. There is bilateral atrophy of the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Neurologic examination shows an ataxic gait and dysarthria. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is positive. Sensation is decreased below the C5 dermatome bilaterally. An MRI of the neck and base of the skull is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a foramen magnum meningioma, as indicated by the MRI. Although the falx cerebri, the supratentorial convex surface, and the sphenoidal wings are the most common locations of meningiomas, in rare cases they also occur at the foramen magnum. Early features include neck pain, which is typically worse with neck flexion and maneuvers that increase ICP (e.g., sneezing). Later, patients present with long tract signs (e.g., sensory and motor deficits that progress from one extremity to the others). Other late findings include spasticity (hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign), gait disturbances, and lower cranial nerve palsies (CN IX–XII), which most likely accounts for this patient's dysarthria and atrophy of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Microscopic examination shows psammoma bodies and concentrically arranged spindle cells.

Meningiomas are slow-growing tumors, patients usually present after several months to years of slowly progressive symptoms, as seen in this patient that progressed in the course of 2-years.
Image Description:

Superior view of internal surface

B) INCORRECT:

A glioblastoma multiforme is most commonly located in the white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and therefore most frequently manifests with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, seizures). The symptoms develop over a short period of time (several weeks) due to rapid growth of the tumor. While the condition can present with motor weakness, the pattern of symptom progression over 2 years seen in this patient is not consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.

C) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytomas are grade I (benign) astrocytomas that are often localized in the cerebellum and most frequently occur in children and young adults. Signs of cerebellar masses include symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, and vomiting), ataxia, and possibly failure to thrive. While an ataxic gait could be caused by a cerebellar tumor, the patient's age, muscle weakness, sensory symptoms, and dysarthria suggest another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis manifests with signs of UMN (e.g., hyperreflexia, spastic paresis) as well as LMN involvement (e.g., atrophy, fasciculations, and flaccid paresis), both of which are present in this patient. ALS may initially present with bulbar symptoms (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia) and/or asymmetric limb weakness, which often begins unilaterally in an upper extremity and progresses during the course of disease. However, her only LMN deficit is the result of a lower cranial nerve lesion (sternocleidomastoid muscle atrophy due to CN XI involvement), whereas other typical LMN lesions are missing (muscle atrophy of the extremities and fasciculations). Also, ALS is usually a rapidly progressive disease that leads to life-threatening symptoms such as respiratory failure (due to paralysis of respiratory muscles) or weight loss and malnutrition (due to dysphagia) within three years, making ALS an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

In syringomyelia, the compression from the fluid-filled cavity within central spinal cord results in neck pain and a cape-like distribution (neck, shoulders, arms) of dissociated sensory loss that develops over years. The sensory symptoms in syringomyelia are often exacerbated by maneuvers that increase the intramedullary pressure (e.g., coughing, sneezing), as in this patient. Muscle atrophy is another common feature of syringomyelia and most commonly affects the small muscles of the hand. Other LMN signs, such as fasciculations and areflexia (rather than this patient's hyperreflexia), may also be present. While spastic paraparesis of the limbs is a possible feature of syringomyelia (involvement of the pyramidal tract and first motor neuron), quadriparesis would be uncommon.
questions.hint: The pattern of this patient's presentation is suggestive of CNS compression in a location that affects both long tracts (cortical) and bulbar tracts.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas typically manifest between 35 and 60 years of age. Headaches and seizures may occur, depending on the size and location of the tumor. However, the motor weakness experienced by this patient would be unusual, and pituitary adenomas with a secretory function would cause endocrine disorders. Additionally, imaging would reveal an intrasellar hyperintense mass with foci of calcification and/or necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells of the cranial and/or peripheral nerves. Acoustic neuroma, the most common schwannoma, typically manifests with sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and facial nerve palsy. However, seizures are uncommon. Additionally, schwannomas appear as heterogeneously hyperintense extra-axial lesions on MRI that are most commonly localized to the cerebellopontine angle. The parasagittal location of this patient's tumor makes schwannoma an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)

A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Metastatic brain tumors may manifest with headache, neurological deficits, and/or seizures. However, they are typically circumscribed, multifocal, intra-axial brain tumors, not extra-axial tumors, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gait

Cerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.

P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum

D) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas are intra-axial tumors that arise from ependymal cells that line the walls of the cerebral ventricles and central spinal canal. They most commonly manifest with signs of hydrocephalus due to their location near the fourth ventricle (in children) or the spinal canal (in adults). On imaging, they appear as intra-axial heterogeneous masses with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and can manifest with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, on CT imaging, they usually appear as hypodense, intra-axial tumors containing focal hyperdense regions (due to calcification and/or hemorrhage). The hyperdense, extra-axial mass seen in this patient makes oligodendroglioma an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (FLAIR sequence; axial plane)

A hyperintense area (green overlay) in the right medial temporooccipital region was hypointense on a contrast-enhanced T1-weighted sequence (not shown). The lesion proved to be an oligodendroglioma. The differential diagnosis on MRI also included ischemic and inflammatory processes.

C: cerebellum; M: mesencephalon (midbrain)

F) CORRECT:

Meningioma is the most common kind of primary CNS tumor with a median age of diagnosis of 65 years. Around half of all cases have a supratentorial location (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove). On imaging, they appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass that is usually hyperdense on CT and isointense to gray matter on plain MRI. On MRI, they appear intense with homogeneous enhancement (as shown in the accompanying image). Most meningiomas show a marginal dural thickening that tapers peripherally (the "tail sign”). They cause symptoms due to extrinsic compression of brain tissue (i.e., mass effect). Parasagittal meningiomas may cause contralateral spastic paralysis due to compression of the motor cortex.

G) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and may manifest with seizures. However, on CT scan, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. The presence of a hyperdense, extra-axial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme unlikely.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastoma

The right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.

Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification
questions.hint: Brain tumors that present with seizures are most often supratentorial. The image shows a dural tail sign. The narrow rim of cerebrospinal fluid around this patient's tumor indicates that it is most likely extra-axial (external to the brain parenchyma).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman with no previous health problems presents to the emergency department with new-onset generalized seizures. Physical examination and laboratory testing, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are unremarkable. Contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain is performed (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant astrocytomas (gliomas) are widely infiltrating lesions with irregular contrast enhancement.

B) CORRECT:

Meningiomas account for 20% of intracranial neoplasms, occur more frequently in women than in men, and tend to be asymptomatic. On MRI, meningiomas are diffusely enhancing lesions that occur most commonly in the parasellar regions of the base of the skull or cerebral convexities. Tumors are adjacent to bone and anchored to the dura, rendering the classic appearance of the “dural tail” on imaging. Calcifications, seen as hypointense regions within the tumor, may be evident on a T2-weighted image. Ensuing symptoms result from the compression of the adjacent brain structures. Typically, tumors alongside hemispheric convexities manifest as seizures and progressive hemiparesis, whereas lesions at the base of the skull lead to cranial neuropathies, such as trigeminal nerve dysfunction, which manifests as facial numbness or facial pain.

Key learning point: A cerebral tumor that is adjacent to bone and anchored to the dura is most consistent with a diagnosis of meningioma.

C) INCORRECT:

Brain metastases are typically seen as multiple lesions with circumscribed margins, localized at the junction of gray and white matter.

D) INCORRECT:

Brain abscesses are typically ring-enhancing lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary central nervous system lymphoma usually appears as a solitary, homogenous, hypointense lesion on MRI, often involving the cerebral hemispheres, periventricular white matter, corpus callosum, subependymal region, deep white matter, and meninges.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. His wife reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metastatic brain tumors may manifest with headache, neurological deficits, and/or seizures. However, they are typically circumscribed, multifocal, intra-axial brain tumors, not extra-axial tumors, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

CT head (with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of lung cancer presenting with weight loss, gradual reduction in consciousness, and deficits in swallowing, speech, coordination, and gait

Cerebellar (green overlay) and brainstem (red overlay) lesions that show intense contrast enhancement are suspicious for metastases.

P: petrous bone; S: sphenoid bone; T with arrows: tentorium cerebellum

B) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas are intra-axial tumors that arise from ependymal cells that line the walls of the cerebral ventricles and central spinal canal. They most commonly manifest with signs of hydrocephalus due to their location near the fourth ventricle (in children) or the spinal canal (in adults). On imaging, they appear as intra-axial heterogeneous masses with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage.
Image Description:

MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)

A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).

Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and can manifest with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, on CT imaging, they usually appear as hypodense, intra-axial tumors containing focal hyperdense regions (due to calcification and/or hemorrhage). The hyperdense, extra-axial mass seen in this patient makes oligodendroglioma an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (FLAIR sequence; axial plane)

A hyperintense area (green overlay) in the right medial temporooccipital region was hypointense on a contrast-enhanced T1-weighted sequence (not shown). The lesion proved to be an oligodendroglioma. The differential diagnosis on MRI also included ischemic and inflammatory processes.

C: cerebellum; M: mesencephalon (midbrain)

D) CORRECT:

Meningioma is the most common kind of primary CNS tumor with a median age of diagnosis of 65 years. Around half of all cases have a supratentorial location (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove). On imaging, they appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass that is usually hyperdense on CT and isointense to gray matter on plain MRI. On MRI, they appear intense with homogeneous enhancement (as shown in the accompanying image). Most meningiomas show a marginal dural thickening that tapers peripherally (the "tail sign”). They cause symptoms due to extrinsic compression of brain tissue (i.e., mass effect). Parasagittal meningiomas may cause contralateral spastic paralysis due to compression of the motor cortex.

Key learning point: Meningiomas are extra-axial, well-circumscribed brain tumors often showing a dural tail on imaging and cause symptoms by compressing adjacent brain tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and may manifest with seizures. However, on CT scan, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. The presence of a hyperdense, extra-axial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme unlikely.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a 69-year old man with a history of personality changes and left-sided hemiparesis from glioblastoma

The right cerebral hemisphere is diffusely abnormal, with intermixed hypodense (green overlay), isodense, and hyperdense (red overlay) areas. There is mass effect with sulcal effacement and midline shift to the left (dashed line). The frontal and occipital horns (arrowheads) of the right lateral ventricle are effaced.

Yellow overlay: choroid plexus calcification
Blue overlay: falx cerebri calcification
questions.hint: Brain tumors that present with seizures are most often supratentorial. The image shows a dural tail sign. The narrow rim of cerebrospinal fluid around this patient's tumor indicates that it is most likely extra-axial (external to the brain parenchyma).

questions.text: You are seeing a 59-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a seizure. According to his wife, he has had recurrent headaches and increasing irritability over the past 3 months. On examination, he has spastic paresis of the right lower extremity and a positive Babinski sign on the right. An MRI of the brain is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas are most common among individuals 40–60 years of age and can manifest with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, on CT imaging, they usually appear as hypodense, intra-axial tumors containing focal hyperdense regions (due to calcification and/or hemorrhage). The hyperdense, extra-axial mass seen in this patient makes oligodendroglioma an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma multiforme almost always occurs in patients over the age of 40 and may manifest with seizures. However, on CT scan, glioblastoma multiforme appears as a poorly demarcated, hypodense, intra-axial lesion that tends to infiltrate along condensed white matter tracts such as the corticospinal tract and the corpus callosum. The presence of a hyperdense, extra-axial mass in this patient makes the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Metastatic brain tumors may manifest with headache, neurological deficits, and/or seizures. However, they are typically circumscribed, multifocal, intra-axial brain tumors, not extra-axial tumors, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Meningioma is the most common kind of primary CNS tumor with a median age of diagnosis of 65 years. Around half of all cases have a supratentorial location (e.g., near the falx cerebri, convex cerebral surface, or olfactory groove). On imaging, they appear as a round, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass that is usually hyperdense on CT and isointense to gray matter on plain MRI. On MRI, they appear intense with homogeneous enhancement (as shown in the accompanying image). Most meningiomas show a marginal dural thickening that tapers peripherally (the "tail sign”). They cause symptoms due to extrinsic compression of brain tissue (i.e., mass effect). Parasagittal meningiomas may cause contralateral spastic paralysis due to compression of the motor cortex.

Key learning point: Meningiomas are extra-axial, well-circumscribed brain tumors often showing a dural tail on imaging and cause symptoms by compressing adjacent brain tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Ependymomas are intra-axial tumors that arise from ependymal cells that line the walls of the cerebral ventricles and central spinal canal. They most commonly manifest with signs of hydrocephalus due to their location near the fourth ventricle (in children) or the spinal canal (in adults). On imaging, they appear as intra-axial heterogeneous masses with areas of necrosis, calcification, cystic changes, and hemorrhage.
questions.hint: Brain tumors that present with seizures are most often supratentorial. The image shows a dural tail sign. The narrow rim of cerebrospinal fluid around this patient's tumor indicates that it is most likely extra-axial (external to the brain parenchyma).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter due to a 1-year history of progressive personality changes, including apathy and irritability. Over the past 3 months, the patient has developed dull, generalized headaches that are worse in the mornings. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. Vital signs are unremarkable. Neurologic examination reveals mild bilateral papilledema, but motor strength, sensation, and reflexes are symmetric and intact. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary, well-demarcated, extra-axial mass over the left frontal convexity. The mass shows intense, uniform gadolinium enhancement and appears to arise from the dura mater. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glioblastoma is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults and can present with personality changes and signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, glioblastomas are intra-axial, highly infiltrative tumors that typically appear on MRI with irregular, ring-like enhancement and central necrosis, not as a well-demarcated, uniformly enhancing, extra-axial mass.

B) INCORRECT:

A low-grade astrocytoma can present with a long history of subtle neurologic changes due to its slow growth. However, they are intra-axial tumors that typically do not enhance with contrast or show only minimal, patchy enhancement on MRI. The intense, uniform enhancement and extra-axial, dural-based location seen in this patient point towards a different etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

While primary CNS lymphoma can present as a solitary, homogeneously enhancing mass, it is an intra-axial tumor, typically located in the periventricular region. It does not arise from the dura. They are more common in immunocompromised individuals, which this patient is not.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with meningioma, a typically benign, slow-growing tumor arising from arachnoid cap cells of the meninges. The gradual onset of personality changes is consistent with a frontal lobe location and slow growth. The morning headaches and papilledema indicate increased intracranial pressure. The MRI findings are pathognomonic: a solitary, well-demarcated, extra-axial mass that is dura-based and demonstrates intense, uniform enhancement. This appearance is due to the tumor's origin outside the brain parenchyma and its high vascularity. These tumors are most common in middle-aged and older women.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerebral metastases are the most common intracranial tumors and can present as solitary, enhancing masses. However, metastases are typically intra-axial, located at the gray-white matter junction, and do not arise from the dura mater. While they can be well-demarcated, the dural-based, extra-axial location in this patient makes a metastasis less likely.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic for evaluation of a new-onset focal seizure that occurred one week ago. She also reports several months of mild, progressive weakness in her right leg and occasional morning headaches. Her medical history is notable for hypertension. On neurologic examination, she has 4/5 strength in her right lower extremity with a subtle pronator drift on the right. An MRI of the brain with contrast reveals a 2.5 cm, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass overlying the left parafalcine region that avidly enhances and demonstrates a 'dural tail' sign. There is minimal surrounding vasogenic edema. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation is a reasonable strategy for small, incidentally discovered meningiomas that are not causing any symptoms, especially in older patients or those with significant comorbidities. However, this patient is clearly symptomatic with a new-onset seizure and progressive focal neurologic deficits, making expectant management inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids, such as dexamethasone, are used to decrease vasogenic edema surrounding a brain tumor, which can temporarily alleviate symptoms. While they may be used as a bridge to surgery, especially with significant edema, this patient has minimal edema. Furthermore, steroids are a palliative measure, not a definitive treatment for the underlying tumor, which is required here.

C) INCORRECT:

Whole-brain radiation therapy is an aggressive treatment used for multiple brain metastases or certain diffusely infiltrating primary brain tumors. It is not indicated for a solitary, well-circumscribed, extra-axial mass that appears benign, as this would expose the entire brain to unnecessary radiation and its associated neurotoxic side effects.

D) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation and MRI findings are classic for a meningioma. The presence of a new-onset seizure and progressive motor weakness is a clear indication for intervention. Surgical resection is the preferred first-line treatment for symptomatic, accessible meningiomas. Surgery provides immediate decompression of the adjacent brain tissue to alleviate symptoms, allows for a definitive histopathological diagnosis and grading of the tumor, and offers the best chance for a cure. The parafalcine location is typically accessible. Most meningiomas are benign (WHO Grade I) and can be cured with complete resection.

E) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) is a treatment option for meningiomas, but it is typically reserved for tumors in surgically inaccessible locations, for patients who are poor surgical candidates, or as adjuvant therapy for residual or recurrent tumors. For a symptomatic and surgically accessible tumor like this one, primary resection is preferred because it provides immediate relief of mass effect and yields a tissue diagnosis, which SRS does not.
questions.hint: The combination of a new-onset seizure, progressive focal neurological deficit, and classic MRI findings suggests meningioma.

questions.text: A previously healthy 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was observed having a seizure. On arrival, she is conscious and reports that she feels drowsy. An MRI of the brain shows a 4-cm, round, sharply demarcated mass. She undergoes resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of a section of the resected specimen is shown. This patient's mass is most likely derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurons very rarely give rise to brain tumors. The vast majority of brain tumors arise from glial cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas arise from blood vessels, which are usually located in the infratentorial region. Microscopic examination would show closely arranged, thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)

Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Astrocytes give rise to astrocytomas. Glioblastoma multiforme (high-grade astrocytoma) is the most common malignant primary brain tumor in adults and usually occurs after the age of 40. Children are more often affected by low-grade pilocytic astrocytomas. Histopathology would show pleomorphic cells clustered around necrotic areas, forming pseudopalisades.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

D) INCORRECT:

Schwann cells give rise to schwannomas, which occur mostly near the cerebellopontine angle. The most common type is an acoustic neuroma, which arises from the vestibulocochlear nerve. Spindle-shaped cells with mixed hypercellular and hypocellular regions are seen on histopathology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a peripheral nerve tumor (H&E stain)

Antoni A area (A): area of high cellularity with Verocay bodies. The Verocay bodies consist of rows of pallisading nuclei (green overlay) interspersed with anuclear eosinophilic areas (red overlay).
Antoni B area (B): paucicellular area with unstained myxoid stroma

This is the typical histological appearance of a schwannoma, a benign tumor of the nerve sheath.

E) CORRECT:

Meningiomas arise from arachnoid cells of the arachnoid villi. They are usually benign tumors that manifest as a slow-growing sharply demarcated mass that is composed of spindle-shaped cells arranged in a whorled pattern. The symptoms they cause are due to compression of adjacent structures, e.g., contralateral spastic paresis due to compression of the motor cortex, personality changes due to compression of the frontal lobe, or focal seizures.

The number of psammoma bodies seen in meningiomas depends on the subtype. The psammomatous subtype seen in this patient is characterized by abundant psammoma bodies. Outside of the CNS, psammoma bodies are seen in papillary carcinoma of thyroid, somatostatinoma, mesothelioma, and serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma of ovary and endometrium.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain; 400x)

Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (yellow overlay) and sheets. The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).

Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

F) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrocytes give rise to oligodendrogliomas, which have cells with clear cytoplasm and a central round nucleus ('fried egg' appearance). They typically arise in the frontal lobe.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows whorls of densely packed cells with multiple areas of lamellated calcification that are known as psammoma bodies. This is the typical histopathological appearance of a meningioma.
